Reviews.Content: This was our second stay here. The hotel has a great relaxed feel. However, public areas are starting to look a little worn. The fitness room was apparently added as a mention when the hotel was built but now there are too many guests who exercise on too few machines. It's also directly next to the spa - so if someones' running on the treadmill don't expect a quiet treatment. Its a great hotel for families but if you're a couple wishing for quiet it's a challenge to find the right room. The hotel also implements an annoying nickel/dime charge for toys/cabanas around pool and beach. Just add $5 to the room and call it a day, would ya? There's also a battalion of concierge staff while one front desk person is trying frantically to help 10 people waiting in line. strange management technique. Other than these needling things, the hotel is fabulous as is most of the staff. I would have to call the 4S next door if you're traveling as a couple...

Reviews.Title: “Jasmine saved our trip - Avoid the holiday weekends if you possibly can”
Reviews.Author: spurg
Reviews.Content: Our rack rate was 515.00 plus 11% for Fairmont suite Self parking is free. There are no daily resort charges. Yahoo Woopie!!! THE POOL: adult pool is very relaxing. Grounds are hige and yes, you will see whales breeching and amazing sunsets. We are a young couple . no kids. It was 100% full. When we checked in on Feb 15th 2006, we stressed how all we really cared about was being quiet. oddly, they gave us room 176. which looked over the fountain. Fine. but it is lobby level with a tiled hall--all night trollies roll back and forth with their wheels clanging about. I will never forget that sound. If you are a light sleeper, avoid lobby level rooms with tiled floors. But if you have kids, the lobby level rooms that open to the pool (104 - 128) are ideal. After complaining, about the noise, they moved us up to 753 which was refurbished. top floor. lovely. great view of the Haleakala. But they failed to tell us about the air conditioning duct that makes this weird grinding sound. ok. yes. i wore earplugs, i had my mobile sound soother, still no sleep night 2 either. 751 is worse. But 755,757,759 are far enough away. top floor. great views of the crater. all refurbished. I called the front desk. they showed my wife another room. (quiet, but not refurbished) i kept insisting on talking to a manager. Finally, this lovely person JASMINE (she's an angel) booked us into 105. this was the room we had honey mooned in. brilliant. you can hear the ocean. refurbished. see photos. Jasmine, you saved our trip. I will write a letter to management on your behalf. Oddly, the receptionist was completely worthless. It is hard to find fault with a place when it is booked to capacity. it was just so busy there. and they are still refurbishing some rooms so not all the rooms are available. This was our third stay at the Kea Lani. Note that i hate hotels it would much prefer a cottage in paia then the touristy hell of wailea. My wife loves hotels. However, I do like the fresh bed sheets every day. In sum, if money is no object, stay in the lower villas. In the main edifice 601, 602 (top floor) have best views of the water and are close enough to hear the waves. 7th floor ocean views are nice too but you can't hear the waves ( if you care about that). If you are stretched and like quiet, i would recommed 103, 105, 107. Study the photos. I hope this helps other light sleepers that are forced to stay there with family. it can be great if you find the right spot!

Reviews.Title: “We loved it!”
Reviews.Author: Teresa567
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Fairmont in a deluxe ocean view suite (we requested a rennovated one and received it). I have high standards in terms of hotels and this place was really great. We did check out the Four Seasons (it was already booked for our dates), but were glad we ended up at the Fairmont....too stuffy, way too crowded, but did have excellent service and Ferraros restaurant...yummy. We had a breakfast buffet included which was very nice, but expensive if not already included. We stayed Feb. 10-15th and never had a problem getting a chair at the pool...there were TONS of open chairs (not all directly overlooking the pool...but close by). The beach is small, but not a problem. The suite was huge with an amazing bathroom and lovely view (#512). We watched whales breeching from the shoreline and from our suite almost daily. Service was excellent. And...the bed...very hard to get out of, because it is sooo comfy. Pluses...They offer free suites if your flight leaves late and you need to shower...and the housekeepers are wonderful even putting our flower leis in heart shapes on the tables and near the bathtub. I loved the packets of Woolite they stock for you too...they really came in handy for quick washing. My only real complaints are: no dimmer switch for the lights in the bathroom (we just bought candles at the grocery store instead), the faucet on the shower didn't let you control temperature and pressure...it all worked as one which was kind of frustrating at times, and buying excursions through the activites desk has quite a bit of a mark-up. Just call the companies direct and get a WAY better deal for most things. South Maui is amazing. West Maui, for us, is just too crowed and Waikiki-like. South Maui is so pretty and relaxing. Big Beach is just down the road and is excellent for swimming and lounging. ENJOY!

Reviews.Title: “Nice hotel but impossible to get a chair!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: The Kea Lani is a great hotel but if you plan on spending time at the pool, be prepared! It is VERY hard to find a chair anywhere the pool. It is not a problem if you don't have children because there is an adult pool with plenty of available chairs. Around the main pool we found that guests were saving chairs before 6am! Having to get up that early to reserve a seat is no vacation for me. I think the problem is that the pool area is rather small and the pool attendants allow this to happen. Besides this problem, we enjoyed ourselves. Next time we will seek out less crowded hotels

Reviews.Title: “Excellent vacation - loved it!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at the Fairmont last week - it was fabulous. There are several pools - if you have kids, there is one with a cool water slide! The service was fantastic and I loved the rooms - we had a suite. The shower is an open shower and the rooms were spacious. We would definitely stay there again!

Reviews.Title: “Loved the Fairmont”
Reviews.Author: djaddis
Reviews.Content: You would think after reading these reviews (and I did before we stayed) that there are TONS of kids here (I loved the reviewer who said "in their droves", like ants or something!) We have a 2 year old but still wanted something that felt upscale and quiet- we LOVED the FAirmont. The hotel was pretty full and we had only paid for a moderate suite so we were worried that we'd be facing the parking lot. When we checked in we had a room on the 2nd floor (not renovated) but overlooking the gardens. We couldn't get a renovated one but we loved the view so we stayed- its not bad at all. the bed was comfy, bathroom great and very, very quiet on the lanai. We spent our time at the baby pool which was very quiet- there did not seem to be tons of kids here at all. Our daughter played with the same handful of other toddlers our entire stay. They were very friendly and helpful- we never had a problem with anyone on the staff. We are avid travelers in very nice hotels and I was extremely impressed by the guests (not snobby at all, unlike what I've heard of the FS), staff, grounds,etc... we were happily surprised and will defintely be back. The moderate suites are a relative bargain (we paid 425) and great for a small family.... We were sad to leave and even sadder when we got to the Westin Ocean Villas- where we spent the 2nd half of our trip....

Reviews.Title: “Paraidse Found”
Reviews.Author: wrcannin
Reviews.Content: The Fairmont was incredible! We will return.

Reviews.Title: “amazing stay!”
Reviews.Author: desertflower2
Reviews.Content: We enjoyed every moment at the Kea Lani. The service was excellent, rooms spacious, and atmosphere delightful. Even though the resort was almost full, there was never a wait, always an open pool chair, and an uncrowded beach. The grounds and staff are large enough to accomodate the capacity. Free parking, complimentary valet, and no daily resort fee. Everyone we met was courteous and helpful. Punch and Lei greeting, poolside server with pineapple, cool towels, or water was a nice touch. Water was brought out to us on the beach as well. Even though the cabanas are for a fee, there was always chairs available in the shade. We really enjoyed Cafe Ciao for both lunch and dinner. The deli is a smart place, serving bakery goods, sandwiches, ice cream, and interesting gifts to return home. Our best dinner was at Seawatch at the Wailea Golf course- best views in Maui IMO. The complimentary canoe paddle each morning was very memorable. A must do! We rented kayaks and crossed in front of the Four Seasons and the Grand Wailea. All we could hear on this Monday morning was the construction behind these hotels- they are building condos. I don't know if I would be too happy staying right across from the noise. We took the beach path to the other resorts- the Grand Wailea was very busy, pool chairs on top of each other and the Wailea beach was crowded. We were happy to return to Polo beach and the Kea Lani. As for children, maybe because it was during the school year but we only saw toddlers- they have their own pool. Never saw a child over five. I think if you have teenagers the GW would be more enjoyable as we saw more kids over there. The adult pool at the Kea Lani was quiet and relaxing- a great place for a poolside massage. I stayed at the Four Seasons in 2002. I agree with most reviews that their service is impeccable and spa is top notch, but the resort itself was somewhat boring and stuffy. I felt more laid back and restful at the Fairmont. Larger rooms, more grounds, quieter beach. It turned into an amazing vacation. BTW, we had ocean view at both the Kea Lani and the Four Seasons. Next time I will choose mountain view and save the money for the spa-the resorts are set back from the beach- you can barely hear the waves.

Reviews.Title: “Second Visit Even Better Than First (if that's possible!)”
Reviews.Author: nalu
Reviews.Content: This was our second stay at Kea Lani and it was even better than our first. We were upgraded to a beautiful ocean view room and since we were traveling with a child, the "two room" set up was fantastic. I've read complaints about children in the "adult pool" but I never once saw this during the 12 days we were there. I was even a little intimidated to go into the adult pool as it was so very quiet & for "romance" only! Regarding the children--we have one child and very high standards for behavior. Not once did I see children misbehaving. There is simply too much fun to be had for children to get board. Our son (10 years old) spent hours, literally, on the beach boogie boarding. We simply could not get him out of the surf! We also snorkeled & he saw his first sea turtle just off the beach--FANTASTIC! We had the breakfast buffet every day (included in our room package). What a way to start the day! Every food you could imagine (buffet is served until 11:00 am). We often would go for a swim in the ocean, take a dip in the pool and then hit the buffet. The staff were wonderful--tending to our every need--especially at the breakfast buffet. The minute the sun started to shine a bit in our eyes, the staff prepared a table in the shade & offered it to us, without us saying anything. This happened every day. I just can't say enough about this place. Yes, it is very expensive. But you get your money's worth. Our son has not stopped talking about Maui & the Kea Lani since we returned!

Reviews.Title: “5 star hotel, on an industrial scale”
Reviews.Author: YUKOR
Reviews.Content: This is a very nice hotel. And so it should be - It's very expensive. The restaurant, bar and beach facilities were all great. I couldnt believe you had to pay $9 per hour for a beach umbrella, but we got over it. We saw at least 3 turtles every time we went snorkelling just off the beach. The sea was beautiful here, with great views across to the old volcanoes up north and out to sea. The pools were great too. I might be 32 yrs old but am not above trying a water slide, and the one at the kid's pool here is a riot. There's a very elegant pool for adults only, which is around the corner from the mass of kids. This is a good touch. The front desk staff were very friendly - and you get garlands and a fruit punch as you arrive. The concierge we found to be a little impatient and aloof. They dont do rooms at the Fairmont, they only do suites. This means you have a sitting room as well as bedroom. And the bathroom is epic. Our room was immaculate and very tastefully set out. Some (minor) objections :- - It's hugh and there are people every where. Perhaps it was the season, but I thought kids only stayed at the Grand Wailea? During our stay they were at the Fairmont too - in their droves. - The hotel was setting out table for a lunch reception outside our hotel window at 3am in the morning (?!). However, staff were extremely apologetic and they threw in a buffet breakfast for us both (normally worth a reassuringly expensive $26pp). - The corridor outside our room was made of rough stone tiles, so bell boys, cleaners, roomservice etc trundling their trollies along here would sound like the latest eruption of Kileau ! If I was to stay in Maui again, I'd go condo living. I think I prefer the self sufficiency and the quieter ambience. However, if 5 star hotels are your thing, you'd be hard pressed to beat Fairmont.

Reviews.Title: “Pretty, but way too noisy!! Pluses but Minus”
Reviews.Author: mstw
Reviews.Content: My husband and I just spent 6 nights at the Fairmont. It was quite an experience. I now understand why there are so many mixed reviews of this hotel. There are some excellent features and amenities, however there are also some very negatives attributes. I keep saying it was a great vacation, but I am not sure I would return to the Fairmont. The Good: Check-in - excellent. The staff was extremely friendly and courtesy. The valet was great, although you have to tip each time you get your car. They greet you with POG (pineapple, orange, and guava juice) and a nice lei. The hotel landscaping is beautiful and the hotel seems airy. We did not eat at the restaurants, but our package included the buffet breakfast. I thought the service was excellent and the food great. The Bad: Our first night's room was extremely noisy. We were in a room near the mechanical room. Why on earth would a hotel have a room near this much noise is beyond belief. I was highly disappointed. They offered to move us to another room, which we did, but this room was not refurbished and looked like something from a '70s garage sale. The refurbished rooms however are beautiful. We were then moved to a garden room - not acceptable. The noise outside the room was horrific. Next stop - partial ocean view. Ok, this was nice, still the walls are very thin. Also, when you open your window to feel the fresh air, you can hear EVERYTHING outside, people laughing or talking. The pool area is very small for my taste and the beach strip was so tiny. This is a mixed review because our service was great and fortunately for us, the hotel was below capacity. Most people checked-out since Thanksgiving had just ended. It would have been horrible if the hotel was full. We are used to beach front property were the beach is a longer than a stone's throw. The Best: Room are beautiful if you get a refurbished room. Housekeeping service, twice daily is excellent. It is great to have a fridge and microwave. We went to the Safeway for snacks and bottle water. The bathrooms have double sink, sunken tub, & separate shower. Restaurant - Cafe O'Lei in the Rainbow Mall. Excellent food, wonderful ambiance. Lastly, the other reviewers are right - this hotel can potentially have too many kids for my taste. However, I am still uncertain if I would return, probably not.

Reviews.Title: “Loved the Fairmont”
Reviews.Author: Kbryant
Reviews.Content: We just returned from a 9 day honeymoon stay at the Fairmont. We fly into Ohau for the first 3 nights and then flew to Maui for the other 9. After reading the reviews here, I was skeptical about the hotel, but I am very pleased to say that our experience was just great. We arrived at 10:00 am and requested a rennovated room and after a few moments of silence on my part, we got it. No complaints at all about the room. It was clean and updated. Perfect. Twice daily maid service, etc. We were greeted with lei's and pog. Throughout the stay, we were addressed by name by just about every employee from the maids to the car valet. Service of employees was fantastic. Pools were a little crowded as some of the others have mentioned. However, the grounds are huge and there is lots of room for everybody. We arrived the week before Thanksgiving and it was fine, however, the families with kids began arriving the week of Thanksgiving and it did get more hectic. The pools are beautiful and we spent our time at the adult pool. Occasionally a kid would venture in, but the attendants were very good about getting them out and on their way. We received fresh pineapple and cool aromotherapy wash cloths daily. We did the walk behind the hotel that connects to the Fours Seasons etc. Very pretty and also a chance to check out the other properties. After seeing the others, we made the best choice by staying at the Fairmont. The Four Seasons pool area and grounds is very small and crowded. In fact, it was terrible. Also, there appeared to be a fair amount of kids in the pool. The Grand Waelai looks better in pictures than in person. The buildings and many of the pool areas look run down. And there were many many kids. As far as kids, there are just a lot of kids everywhere in this part of the island. The Fairmont has a car that takes you short distances and we used this several times, even though we had car. Very professional. Used to spa for several services and they were all great. Only complaint is that the waiting area is a little small - the services made up for it. We also got hair cuts at the onsite salon. They were good, but pricey. Also had a manicure here but it only lasted a short while and I wasn't happy with it. After driving around, found a great place for a manicure/pedicure, The Nail Shop. Much better. Some restaurant suggestions: Stella Blues, Tommy Bahamas, Cheeseburger and Mai Tais. Overall, our experience was top notch. I have been to nice places like some of the others posting here, but I found this to be a wonderful hotel and place to honeymoon. We'll be back. Classy without being snobby.

Reviews.Title: “Fabulous, elegant resort!”
Reviews.Author: pattyatips
Reviews.Content: I am literally fighting the jet lag as I write this but wanted to post ASAP as this sight helped so much with our planning. I read some of the negative reviews and just don't get it. This resort is beautiful and extremely upscale without being pretentious (i.e. next door at the Four Seasons). We were here over Thanksgiving and did not find it crowded at all. Never had a problem getting a pool chair and the beach was great. Fresh leis and cold towels upon check in and oh, those suites! I cannot tell you how nice it was to be in a suite after 5 days in a regular hotel room in Kaanapli. Yes, there are children here. I never once saw bad behavior, just kids being kids. FYI-lots of nannies helping the parents out and keeping them entertained. The lawn around the pool area is very spread out and there are plenty of spots for one to find that are away from the crowd, so to speak. After walking thru the FS next door, I could not believe how jam packed they are over there. Yes, I know the service is fab, but I don't necessarily want to hear all the details of my neighbors dinner the night before. At the Fairmont, you don't have to, LOTS of room. Also, I did not see any construction of hear any this past week. Finally, do not miss the opportunity to dine at Nicks. It was our BEST meal on the island and the service was over the top. I have stayed at many a Four Seasons, Ritz, Peninsula, etc...and I would rate the Fairmont Kea Lani right there with them.

Reviews.Title: “Don't Believe The Negative Reviews”
Reviews.Author: PKCinLA
Reviews.Content: Honeymooned at at the Kea Lani from Nov. 12 through Nov 19. Read some of the negative reviews before going but came away without any complaints. Bottom line: this is one of the finest resorts on Maui. Booked a standard room but were upgraded to a renovated room upon request. Facilities and service were great. Our room had a refrigerator and microwave oven as well as a DVD player. Complimentary washer and dryer on our floor was a pleasant surprise. The suite was spacious and clean, but the style was not necessarily luxurious. The grounds and pool area were well maintained and not overcrowded as some reviewers pointed out. However, we were not there during the high season. We did most of our own research and made our own reservations in terms of activities and restaurants, but the concierge was very good about helping us rent a car. Nick's is a must for dinner but it, like most restaurants in the area, are pricey. More reasonable prices can be found in nearby Kihei. Also visit the local Safeway to stock up on drinks and snacks. Try the smoked salmon at the breakfast buffet. Overall, would recommend the Kea Lani without hesitation.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful time at the Fairmont”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My wife and I stayed at this hotel in Mid-September and booked the Deluxe Ocean View room, and were upgraded to the Villa upon arrival. For a honeymooning couple wishing to spend time together and relax, this is a wonderful place. Even though I had a slight flu during our time in Hawaii, I still had a wonderful time. The breakfast buffet's are great with a huge variety of food (although the birds flying around the eating area get annoying, but then again you won't escape them). Our room was very clean, and maid and room service were always available upon request. The hotel is far from the big city (Honolulu) type experience, and is tucked away and very private. Night time walks around the grounds are quiet and peaceful, and during the day, there are plenty of things to do in and around the area. I'd personally stay at the Fairmont in future visits.

Reviews.Title: “First Class Hotel”
Reviews.Author: kim h
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Kea Lani for part of our 13 day trip to Hawaii and it was wonderful. I don't understand what the complaints are about. They treat you wonderfully and rooms are awesome. The pools were great, the rooms were better. They have free valet parking and as soon as you drive up there is someone opening the drivers door as well as the passanger door, taking any bags you may have out of the back seat and handing them to you. There are free in room safes, small refridgerator and microwave. The room was very clean and gorgeous. If you don't like this hotel, you don't like any hotel, anywhere. The grounds are very clean and well kept, very friendly staff as well. They will give you tips on where to go on the island and where the locals like to eat. The prices for food at the hotel are very costly. The one day I spent lounging all day by the pool it cost me $26 for a burger, fries and soft drink. However, there are plenty of places to eat within 2 to 10 minute drive, depending on where you want to go. Stay away from Nick's Fishmarket, way overpriced and the food was horrible. Service there was great. It was $140 for 2 people and we each had 1 drink from the bar. I loved the location of the hotel, becuase it wasn't in the center of town and the tourists really like Lahina instead anyway, which is about 45 minute drive. All it is is a bunch of shops that the cruise ships drop their passangers off to see and for those who don't know better to stay there. The Fairmont was easy to get to from the air port, approximately 30 minutes away, but then again so are all the other sides of the island. The beach area is nice and clean with plenty of chairs to lounge in. The tour desk is a bit pricy so go to Boss Frog's or Snorkel Bob's, you can book excursions much cheaper through them and rent snorkel gear, boogie boards, etc by the day or week. We did that for Molokini Island and the sunrise bike ride down the volcano. Feel free to e-mail me if you have any questions.

Reviews.Title: “Enjoyed our Stay”
Reviews.Author: Quinnly
Reviews.Content: I will preface this by saying we don't often stay in 4 or 5 star hotels so for us, this was a bit of an extravagance at the nightly price. For those who regularly stay in very swanky places, I may understand some of the cooler reviews, however, here is mine... We arrived after check in time and were greeted by leis and punch. We had only booked the garden room, but asked if upgrade was available and received a partial ocean view which means you can see the ocean from the lanai of the bedroom. We did have to settle on two double beds versus a king to get the upgrade, but I wanted the view. We were not sure if we had a renovated suite or not, but think we did. Very roomy and the bathroom was my favorite part. Room had small refrigerator and even a microwave which was nice. We had twice daily maid service and I thought the evening service was even better than the day. Always had fresh supply of towels which is great when you are showering a couple times a day. I thought the various pools were very nice, if yes, a little cool at first. We stayed at the one with the pool bar. At this time of year which is shoulder season, not hard to get chairs and umbrella. Yes, there were some kids, but I thought very few and they did not come up to that pool area except to use the slide which originates up there. And at the adult pool, I hever saw any kids. I guess it really depends on time of year. I thought pool service was good, even though we did not use it much. I thought the pool area was always clean. I agree that there was virtually no night life with exception of restaurants and Nick's FishMarket was probably our favorite meal on the island. We had a lovely table and excellent service and food. Was pricey, but pretty standard for Wailea. I think there was a guitarist at the other restaurant, but again, I was suprised no managers cocktail party, any other live entertainment. But we really didn't care. The pathway that links the Wailea resorts was one of the favorite things we did every morning. We could walk to the other resorts, the shops at Waleia, etc. The resort offers shuttle service around the area to restaurants, golf, shops so if you don't plan on renting a car, this is helpful to avoid taxi fees. I would highly recommend joining the Fairmont President's Club. You can do the first level for free which I did it it got you some extras like free paper, free local calls, and best of all, complimentary use of golf clubs. I had a beautiful set of ladies Taylor Mades and never drove the ball better. Helps if you don't want to bring clubs to island. Overall, my husband and I were very pleased with the Fairmont. Chrissy Quinn

Reviews.Title: “Kea Lani is okay, but not worth the price.”
Reviews.Author: Outside4
Reviews.Content: I am having a hard time in really wanting to give this 2 circles instead of 3, but I will give it 3 for the suite we had and to be nice. I just got back 4 days ago from a 10 day honeymoon that included a stay for 5 days in Maui at the Kea Lani. My wife and I really wished now we stayed at the Four Seasons next door (we visited there for dinner at Spago's and a beach walk), especially after having just stayed at a Four Seasons on anothe island. Oh well, next time. The Good part: The room was very nice and roomy. The reason we thought we wanted to stay at the Kea Lani over others in Wailea was because you get a nice sized suite with separate living room, and it is a Fairmont Hotel. The room we had was clean and comfortable, and we had a great peaceful view of the ocean from the 5th floor in our position. Bathroom and bedroom were clean and nicely done. The Hotel is spacicious and very open aired, and some staff seem friendly enough in their jobs. There are some star customer service moments, like our masseuses at the Spa. The Bad Parts: For the price, the Kea Lani is not worth it compared to the competition. The facilities are trying to be top notch, but they simply are not. We would see bottles and drinks laid down around the place and pools that seemed to sit for too long. The place is a machine for placing in and spitting out hundreds of people and their staff operate in this mode. Many of their staff just aren't thinking "resort" even though it is on the building, and simply want to move you on and get you out of their faces. Not good. One prime example is how the bartendar at the Ciao restaurant rolled his eyes and was a lump of coal because I was ordering my favorite Mojito drinks (they take a little more work to make then throwing in a shot of rum and pressing a button). Another is how at their Spa when we came in for our appointments the greet/register person who was talking to a friend, kept talking a little longer and acted like we were in their way. Not good for spending $300 on two Spa treatments. Another example is how the Concierge desk closes at 9PM. Or another is how staff walk by you and look away from you so they don't have to say "hi". There are more examples, but maybe this gives you an idea. And get this - we were there on the off-season. They nickel and dime you. This aggravated me coming in from a Four Seasons. I don't mind paying good money to go to a good resort, but then I don't expect to be nickle and dimed for small stuff. For example, $10/hr to get into an office to get on the internet, $9/hr for an umbrella at the beach, $75 fee for use of a pool cabana, $4 fee for "in-room" service to bring up $26 of bottled water. What the hell was the "in-room" service about since I am ordering from a in room bar menu in the first place??? Also $1 phone charge to even an 1-800 number. Four Seasons doesn't do this to you. And the Fairmont was not the much less in price then then in Wailea. The food their was not good, especially at $25-35 a plate. The dining amenities were average. Avoid the breakfast buffet. At $26 a person, the food there was old and bland, the fruit was aged. I have had much better ones. Fortunetly you are near Kihea and other very good dining is available nearby. They do have a Ciao Deli on site that has good snack foods and items. That at least was there to go to. The pool facilites were average, and I believe due to the suites a lot of parents bring children there. Thus you have a lot of kids running around. We were off-season so it was probably better than it is during on season I would imagine. The Spa needs some help. It is very small, think gym locker room. You can see they try, but for the men's room they only "extras" for products looked directly out of an old-school barber shop I have been too. Ouch! The woman's side wasn't much better. Then the waiting area is actually an end of a hall with a candle and some tea. Cramped if another couple shows up. The massage table and area was fine, and we had a good tandem massage treatment with good staff there. All in all, I would say it is an average resort in a good location, which asks for too much money. If we go back to Wailea, you will not find us there.

Reviews.Title: “Big Resort - Lots of kids and thin on the night life....”
Reviews.Author: SavethePandas
Reviews.Content: We spent five nights at the Kea Lani and we really did enjoy the experience...however, it wouldn't be my first choice if we ever went back to Maui. The Kea Lani rooms were quite nice and we had a lovely ocean view. We enjoyed the beach and had a great kayak/snorkel tour that was excellent. We also did some fun private snorkeling down past Makena that was great and close by so location was good. Golf and tennis also excellent. yoga was so-so...we aren't pool people so the loads of kids there didn't bother us ... we were just surprised by the lack of a good lobby bar for a pre-dinner cocktail and lack of any sort of social night life. we ended up spending our evenings at the Four Seasons down the way - a nice walk along the beach - food there was excellent and the lobby bar was fun. overall - good experience but if you are sans children - maybe try the Four Seasons.

Reviews.Title: “Lovely Resort”
Reviews.Author: proppy
Reviews.Content: I'm another one with mixed reviews. My overall experience was pleasant, The Fairmont Kea Lani is lovely, with very nice rooms. I must admit that I was worried about the rooms after reading a few reports here but my room was very nice and comfortable, yes, it may have lacked in the extra little touches that the Four Seasons next door would give you, but it didn't matter. Our friends were staying at The Four Seasons, the room was slightly more luxurious but the actual structure was ugly and the atmosphere pretentious. Our friends liked our resort much more as it was "friendlier" in their words and "prettier". The Wailea area was very nice. A few negatives, when we checked in we were told we had a lovely view of the beach (it was a slight side view). A few times room service trays with plates etc were left outside the rooms for quite a while. In my opinion the SPA was very small and not the best. On the whole the Resort was very very nice.

Reviews.Title: “Absolutely Amazing”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My family and I had an absolute blast at the Fairmont Kea Lani! They had amazing restaurants on the hotel site. Plus about a mile or so walk way leading to the mall called the "Shops of Waliea", which took you past all the other neighboring hotels. Very scenic and beautiful. The beach was sculpted by amazing lava rocks and the most beautiful water around! Upon arriving at the Kea Lani you are greeted by hawaiian workers and recieve beautiful fresh lei's. The rooms were very clean and high class. As well as the creative designs of the three pools. There were always workers walking around with free fresh pineapple and towels. Excellent service. From the beach there is a beautiful view of the other islands and their outstanding volcanoes, as well as molokini! If you stay here I highly recommend the blue water rafting adventure which took us into lava caves, turtle town and molokini. We also saw dolphins and got extremely close to a hump back whale and her calf. I also recommend going on a down hill bike adventure. We woke up extremely early and went to the top of a volcano and watched the sun rise! Then when that was all done we rode a bike ALL the way down the volcano... which was only about 300 yards of pedalling! We also attended a luau in lahina which was very very cool with great food... great history! All in all an amazing trip to remember! Highly recommended!

Reviews.Title: “Kea Lani is 2nd best Maui hotel but that's not saying much”
Reviews.Author: Vivi28
Reviews.Content: Let me save you some time and trouble. If you want 5 star fabulous-ness, don't go to Maui. We stayed 7 nights at the Fairmont. It was decent. I've stayed in much better and much worse. It's not 5 star but it really IS the second best hotel in the Wailea area of Maui (Four Seasons being the best). When I read all of the reviews, I couldn't understand how they could be so contradictory but it's true. The Fairmont has a lovely lobby and pool area, lovely romantic restaurants (Caffe Ciao is actually more romantic and less expensive than Nick's Fishmarket) and a nice (but tiny) spa. It also has rooms that are mediocre (although the bathrooms are fabulous) even after renovations, filthy patio furniture in the rooms AND at the pool, and so-so service even in the least busy season. I had never been to Hawaii so I had this image in my head of it being pure 5 star paradise but it's really more like the land the 80s forgot. The buildings are aging and it shows. I also thought that if I was paying $600 a night for a deluxe ocean front suite, it would be one of the best room I've ever seen--also wrong. That's just how it is on Maui though way overpriced and so-so. I live in Florida and for my money (and traveling time!) all things being equal I'd rather go to a newer, cheaper, closer fabulous resort in the Carribbean. I'm glad I did the Hawaii thing and we did have a fun trip but if you're expecting the best trip of your life based on price alone, you're going to be disappointed. We checked out the Four Seasons (lovely but no breeze or air conditioning in the lobby and hallways so it was STIFLING) and the rooms looked tiny and didn't have great views (most rooms face each other in a courtyard setting). For the money, big deal! The Grand Wailea is a big tacky Vegas-like place (there's even a wedding chapel by the pool) that was absolutely teaming with people. Everyone there seemed drunk and happy though so if that's your type of thing you might enjoy it. The Maui Prince looks like a 70's office building. Fake wood trim. Just hideous. If you're going to Maui and you want to stay in the Wailea area (best weather by far!) pick the Fairmont. If you pick Four Seasons you'll get a view of your neighbor's balcony in a shoe box room for $800/night. At least at the Fairmont, it's not 100 degrees and you can see the ocean. Or if you want a big drunken crowd, the Grand Wailea is probably the 3rd choice and I believe it's a little cheaper (probably why it's so crowded).

Reviews.Title: “Great experience”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My wife and I just returned from 7 days at the Kea Lani and have to say we can't wait to go back next year. From the time we arrived the staff was pleasant and courteous, the hotel and grounds were beautiful, and our suite was simply amazing. I agree that all the resaurants were overpriced but which ones aren't in the Wailea area? To combat that we had gone to the nearby Safeway and stocked the fridge so we wouldn't have to eat all of our meals out. The staff was courteous enough that we called to have plates and sivlerware brought up to make sandwiches, they were there within minutes. There were children running around but not in the adults pool. The children we did come across by the waterslide were well behaved and one even found my wifes sunglasses and turned them into the lifeguard. If there were anything I think could have been improved is that the activities desk wasn't that helpful in finding activities outside of the pamphlets that are there, if you want to do something outside of the snorkeling tour/helicopter ride/dinner cruise type, you're on your own to find them. Also, the private Polo beach was our favorite of all the beaches we had visited. We wouldn't think of staying anywhere else.

Reviews.Title: “Loved the Kea Lani”
Reviews.Author: bsg1003
Reviews.Content: We pulled up to the Kea Lani to be greeted by the Bell Captains and Valets eager to help us into the lobby area. The cool towels and refreshing beverages were just what we needed after our trip from the east coast. Check in was a breeze and we were upgraded to a Deluxe Full Ocean View suite on the 6th floor. The bell captain gave us a detailed tour of the resort and showed us to our suite. The suite was delightful; 2 sinks, sunken bathtub; stall marble shower. The living room had a pullout couch with a desk and wet bar set-up. The bedroom had a king size bed that had thick, fluffy linens. The suite was made-up twice daily with orchids sprinkled throughout the suite. In room dining was delicious and was available 24 hours a day. The weather was picture perfect and the resort has never looked so beautiful. The pools were glistening and the beach was combed. Overall, a pleasure to stay at the Kea Lani !

Reviews.Title: “Pretty, roomy, but not quite as clean or as much value as expected”
Reviews.Author: DJDVG
Reviews.Content: The Fairmont's design, lobby, and facilities are over the top- absolutely breathtaking and unique. The concierge staff is extremely helpful and busy all of the time. Valet parking is complimentary, which makes getting in and out easy. Beautiful pools complete with water slides. We loved the huge bathroom with soaking tub and shower, and two sinks, and we loved the size of the room. The things we noticed that were less favorable were that the room was a little bit dingy- carpet and upholstery. The sheets or blankets, or something in the room had a damp smell. We found a roach in our room, which isn't completely out of place in Hawaii, so not so unusual. While eating breakfast on the patio, there was a smashed roach on the door right behind us, again, not entirely unexpected, but for the price we pay to be there and eat breakfast ($$$), we'd expect everything to be clean. We'd just come from another resort in Kapalua, and the comparison was that Fairmont needs to keep things a lot cleaner. We'd stay in the Fairmont again, definitely, since the property is beautiful, but if there was a better deal to be found elsewhere, we'd probably try another property first.

Reviews.Title: “Great Trip”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Just returned from a great trip to Maui. We have a 3 year old and we didn't leave the property very often, so the resort quality was important. We had a fabulous time! The pool was perfect for our 3 year old who loved the slide. We used a poolside cabana almost every day which was definitely worth the money. The staff, every one of them, with exception of the concierge, was great! The activities desk booked us a great snorkeling trip. The front desk and all restaurant servers were helpful and friendly. After reading some of the reviews I was a bit nervous about the accomodations, but we were very happy. The rooms were clean and spacious. We only ordered a mountain view, but were satisfied with the view. We did ask for a renovated room and they honored that request. We returned to our room everyday for "nap time" at 1:00 and service was already complete. Turn down service was timely as well. Our only gripe was the concierge who gave us a few bad recommendations and didn't really seem to care about their service. We had better luck researching restaurants on the internet. Overall, a fantastic time!

Reviews.Title: “Amazing resort ”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My husband and I went there for our honeymoon and had an amazing time. The staff was very nice and would do anything to make our stay more pleasant. We were upgraded to a suite when they found out we were honeymooners!! They even moved our luggage for us and we didn't have to bother with a thing. The activites desk helped us with all of our bookings and we had a great time on all of our excursions! I would definetly go back to the Fairmont!! The room was beautiful and the bathroom was huge!! Our trip to Maui was just like a fairy tale!!

Reviews.Title: “Loved it - great resort and great service!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My husband & I stayed at the Fairmont Kea Lani the week of 9/17 celebrating our 10th anniversary. We had previously stayed at the Four Seasons next door for our honeymoon. After reading some of the reviews posted, we were quite nervous about the service, condition of the rooms and large numbers of kids at the resort (we were lucky to leave the kids back home with Grandma!) I agree with other reviewers that it is very expensive for what you get but I am not sure what people expect - it's Wailea and things are really pricey there!!! We were overall very impressed with the hotel and did not see signs of any of the things mentioned in some of the more critical reviews on this board. The service was outstanding - everyone was extremely friendly and said Aloha at every turn. b The ladies at the concierge desk were great and recommended an outstanding local sushi place called Sansei. Everything we needed regarding service was always right there and everything seemed very efficient. Twice daily housekeeping kept everything fresh too. The only area that seemed to be a challenge for them was getting the paper to us each day (we had asked for something other than the local paper so I think it kept getting mixed up). Our room was beautiul - we were on a corner so it was a little larger. Well-equipped and v. comfortable. They include a mini-fridge and microwave which is great so you can store drinks bought at the market at much lower prices than the resort charges. The adult pool was great - nice and quiet. I thought we would have a problem getting chairs since I had read people reserved them early in the morning but we were able to sit exactly where we wanted each day. The beach was great too - they have a nice little crescent of beachfront (see pics attached!) I will say that we may have been there on a quiet week since the day we left the resort seemed a lot more crowded with loud people. Regarding restaurants, in addition to Sansei (which we ate at twice it was so good! Go by 5PM on Sundays - there's a line out the door since they do a half-price special), we loved Spago at the Four Seasons (great flavors, impeccable service, awesome view and liked Seawatch at the Golf Club (great food, attentive (if somewhat slow) service). Nick's Fishmarket at the Fairmont was good but nowhere near as fabulous as it was made out to be on this board and of course, very expensive. For a comparable price, we liked Spago much better. For lunch, Cheeseburgers, Mai Tai's and Rock & Roll at the Shops at Wailea offers a nice, lower cost option compared to the $16 burgers at the hotel. Also, Caffe Kihei in town had a pretty good inexpensive breakfast and the place was packed. The other restaurant at the Fairmont and the pool bar both were nothing great and very pricey. One feature that was great at the Fairmont was the Cafe - we were able to buy muffins and juice/coffee each day for around $10 which was nice if we didn't want to go out or weren't hungry for the big, expensive buffet breakfast. That cafe was a nice convenience compared to other high-end resorts. Overall, we really liked this hotel but I would give an edge to the Four Seasons when comparing the two, especially for those traveling without kids. We just really wanted to stay somewhere different this time.

Reviews.Title: “5 Star ? I don't think so.”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: 1. My wife and I made reservations for an 'ocean view' suite. They gave a suite with a view of the cean but you needed to stand outside on the balcony and look around the corner to see it. We complained and got a bad attitude from the Manager, Steven who thinks ocean-view and partial-ocean-view are the same thing. 2. The only restaurant on the property where you can eat breakfast was infested with birds every morning. A few birds are charming, but 25 agressive birds on your breakfast table is very annoying. Also, because of the birds, there was not a 'clean' chair to be found. 3. The property maintenance and management needs attention. I will not be a guest again especially at $550.00+ per night.

Reviews.Title: “Can't wait to go back!”
Reviews.Author: mskimfm
Reviews.Content: We just got home last night and can't wait to go back. We ended our 12 day honeymoon with a 5 night stay at the hotel. We went on a cruise first...Pride of Aloha (very disappointing). The hotel was beautiful, the room and view were excellent. The staff was friendly and our room was always clean, housekeeping was on top of it. The pools were great and beach access was very cool. The problems I had were with the Italian restaurant and checking in. The restaurant wasn't that good and the food was totally overpriced (the breakfast/brunch buffet was excellent but overpriced). We also got to the hotel around 12pm and didn't get into the room until after 4pm. Thankfully we had a car and went to a local shopping center. We were there last week and the crowds died down after Labor Day weekend. There were families around but not a problem. We swam in the family pool with the waterslide and had a great time! We loved this hotel!

Reviews.Title: “Go To The Four Seasons”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: All size no substance. Dated Furniture. Dirty, filthy Rooms. Awful Restuarants. Nicks was good. Atmosphere is low end at best. Staff was nice but low end also. They have no idea opulence is about. For 500 a night they should learn. I was there on my Honeymoon. I left after the second day and went to the four seasons. Got a sweat for 750 a night. Totally worth it. Such a great hotel. If you are a private person like myself do not make the same mistake I did.

Reviews.Title: “A great stay!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I visited the Fairmont Kea Lani with my family (parents, 21 year old sister, 18 year old brother and my boyfriend, 27) in January. This was a first time stay for all of us, having previously stayed at the Westin and on other islands. Upon check-in we were told that they were overbooked in the standard ocean view rooms, we had booked two, and offered to upgrade us to a villa for no additional charge. It was awesome! Two bedrooom, two bathroom villa with a full kitchen and private dipping pool. We couldn't have asked for a nicer setup! The bedrooms were large, the bathrooms even larger and the view was stunning! I've read many complaints about there being too many family's, if you want an all adult resort, then go to one! I prefer peace and quiet, however, this resort is somewhat geared to family's, you should expect there to be some children! I do agree that all too frequently there were children in the adult pool and the staff never did anything about that. As for it being overpriced, when you stay at a hotel of this calibur you should expect the meals to be slightly more expensive, it's par for the course. We bought fresh fruit and muffins to keep in our room as an alternative to paying for their breakfast. We ate lunch at the hotel everyday, the food was great! Especially the fish wrap, get it with mahi-mahi!!! The staff was wonderful, constantly feeding us fresh pineapple and bringing us cool towels as we layed in the sun. Overall, it was a great place to stay if you want to relax, with great service, food and beautiful rooms. If you're looking for a bargain, don't stay at a $500+/night hotel!

Reviews.Title: “Great Service -Revenue Manager”
Reviews.Author: PCTravel
Reviews.Content: Just want to pass on a good story. We had made a reservation at the Fairmont for between Christmas and New Years. The booking agent and made a mess out of the reservation - type of room, rate, etc. I was referred to the Revenue Manager to sort it out. The Fairmont really stepped out to the plate and got everything worked out. It is great to see this level of customer service !! We are looking forward to our trip.

Reviews.Title: “Honeymoon Trip”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: After reading these reviews...and being at the Kea Lani at the EXACT time--I would have to agree with them. my now Husband and I were at the Kea Lani for our last 5 days of our honeymoon. We did not had horrible expieriences as the others...but I did read some reviews before we left that said you should ask for a renovated room before you check in! Glad we did that!!! Our room (210) was lovely. The bathroom was large and beautiful. The bedroom was nice...but not like WOW! it was just "nice". The large balcony was lovely. We did the poolside cabana dinner and it was nice. I think we got lucky with the kids running around...because it was nice and quiet. I did notice there are stairs that divide the cabanas to the rest of the cafe. What the cafe does to keep people out of the area is put up a barrier. I thought that was cool when we arrived. But...when we got there the waiter took it down...so families started walking down the steps and walking right past our cabana--talking loud and being rude. TOO MANY FAMILIES!!! I was annoyed by that. I wish the staff would have thought about keeping the barrier up for privacy. Another issue I had was the adult pool. Now, My now husband and I are on vacation. We do not want to get up at the crack of dawn and put a towel and "claim" a lounge chair. I was appaled that people actually do that. It was my understanding that the Fairmont has a policy that you cannot do that...but nobody cared to stop it. Which was annoying. I am sorry-but I am paying almost $700/night and would like to NOT worry about these sort of things. I would also like to mention the rudeness of children there. My Husband and I were walking to the Spa to get massages and a little boy just ran right into me. With his rich Mom right there. Literally BANG right into me. I was soooo annoyed! What has happened to "WOW I am sorry!" But the rich Mom didn't even care to notice. This is the case all over the hotel. I would also like to mention the Pool Bar. I completely agree that the Pool Bar should be at the Adult Pool. Why would anyone with any sort of brain put a bar at the family/kids pool?? I don't get it. Overall, the prices at the Fairmont were VERY PRICEY! It would be better to go to the nearby Safeway and stock up on Milk, Cereal and Coke. Overall, it was a lovely hotel with lovely grounds. I would not stay here again because of the price and the attitude of the hotel as a whole. I will stay at Kaanapali and be with normal, level headed people.

Reviews.Title: “never again”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: To get to the point I will make this short and sweet. I went to the Fairmont to get married, have a romantic stay, and relax. This was the wrong choice. This resort only caters to families with tons of kids and babies. We are members of the Fairmont Presidents Club and were supposed to get a news paper every day. Did we? We got one the very first day and never again. When we told the front desk about it, they said they would fix the problem but they never did. Nicks fishmarket is totally overrated....Awful service. I actually was in my wedding dress and had to get up and pour myself some more wine......The waiters were slow and non existent. I will never again stay here. It didn't ruin my wedding or honeymoon but it didn't make it any more special either.

Reviews.Title: “Don't Believe the Negative Reviews”
Reviews.Author: Allison1967
Reviews.Content: I can't believe that anyone would bash this resort. We've stayed at the Fairmont Kea Lani several times (we're going again in November) and I have nothing negative to say about it, except for the fact that you may have to walk a long way from the common areas to your room. If you don't want to run into crowds, especially kids, than don't travel to Hawaii during peak seasons, i.e. summer. The best time to visit Hawaii is in the fall - when there are few crowds and even less kids, due to school. Plus, the rates are less expensive. I always take my two young boys and we have quality family time. People with children pay just as much money to stay at a resort as couples do and spend even more money when it comes to food and activities (that's why resorts love families and cater to them). If you don't want to run into children, I recommend staying at the Kona Village Resort on the Big Island during couples only season. Remember, we were all once children. As for the resort, the beach is awesome (smooth sand and great waves for bodysurfing and boogie boarding), the pools are wonderful (there's a waterslide, toys, a basketball hoop and a swim-up bar), the rooms are huge (the bathroom alone is the size of a small hotel room). There's a big soaking tub, a separate walk-in shower with tremendous water pressure, a separate toilet and double sinks. The bedroom is separate from the living room where there's a pull-out sofa and entertainment center. There's two TV's, two telephones, a refrigerator and a microwave. Plus, a double balcony with a table and chairs. The staff is excellent - I've never run into someone who isn't kind and helpful. I understand that they're currently refurbishing their rooms and we hope to stay in one in November. However, if we don't, it won't ruin our vacation. Hawaii is expensive, but worth it. Trust me, you won't regret staying here.

Reviews.Title: “Unbelievable Resort - but too many kids!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: You've got to go during the right time of year. Check ahead to make sure that there are no conventions and avoid the peak kid times (Summer, Xmas, etc.). We had the mixed fortune of going during the Maui film festival, so it was a bit like West Hollywood in Maui - too many producer-types reading scripts and talking on three cell phones at the same time. Of course, it was kinda neat to see all the stars (many were staying in the villas at the Kea Lani), but it made the crowds unbearable. In fact, we almost left to go to the Ritz Kapalua for some peace and quiet. The resort itself is incredible, maybe a little on the large and unmanageable size, but nothing compared to the Grand Wailea. Great restaurants - Nicks was one of the best meals we had on the island. Relatively attentive staff, but they weren't on the same level as the Ritz or Four Seasons. Our room was unreal - top floor suite overlooking "adult" pool and the ocean. Not cheap, though. Once the film festival crowd left it was a totally different resort, but other guests we spoke with who had been there previously said that during any convention it gets crazy. I've been to Maui several times, and this was the first time I stayed in Wailea (been to Kapalua once and Kaanapali several times). The weather was better down south (although it did rain twice, that is unusual), but all in all Kaanapali was more enjoyable for me. Of course, if you're traveling with a family, this place would be a good choice. But I agree with some of the other reviews - if you want to be assured of peace and quiet, stay at the Four Seasons or the Ritz Kapalua.

Reviews.Title: “Nice (not fabulous) hotel, Not for honeymooners!”
Reviews.Author: Windlassie
Reviews.Content: Let me add my husband and I to what appears to be a growing list of dissatisfied recent guests of the Kea Lani. We were there from Aug. 17 - 24, not only for our honeymoon, but to be married on Maui. I had let them know ahead of time this was our purpose. As a previous poster emphasized, we are also usually easygoing, easy to please people. (Please refer to our review of Goria's Spouting Horn B&B on Kauai, to see that we can be pleased.) We booked a Deluxe Ocean View room and figured that we would have a slim chance of a honeymoon upgrade. But we didn't expect to have to fight for what we paid for. We didn't even get leis when we checked in. Our understanding was that all the suites are the same, but that the floor determines the quality because of the view. The lobby area, as previously stated by others, was always hectic and loud. We were taken to our room (524) to discover that it directly overlooked the "upper" pool with a million screaming kids. Not exactly our honeymoon dream. We called the front desk to inquire if there were other comparable quality rooms available near the adult pool and were given a key to go look at another room (456). Now if my understanding is correct, this is not a deluxe ocean view room by definition. The room was not nearly as nice as the first. Strange foul odor, worn upholstery, stained carpet, stained walls and stained bedspread! I was apalled that such a room even existed at the Fairmont. I was very disappointed that they tried to pass this off on us. So we went back and said it wouldn't work. After much deliberation they offered us the room we ended up with (658). My guess is they were holding it for someone "special" whoever that might be. This room had a fabulous view and nice accomodations. But after 14 hours traveling, and given that we were there for our wedding, at $665 per night, we shouldn't have had to go through this. And, though moved away from the kids' pool, we ended up with a screaming monster in the room next door anyhow. The previous post about the outrageous prices is also true. I sent my wedding gown with housekeeping to have it steamed. They charged me $60 and it came back stained!!! We ordered in-suite dining on our lanai for our wedding night, this was all arranged ahead of time. They did not even give us a complimentray split of champagne or anything. The room, though nice, was not 5 star. It could have been cleaner. Towels were not plush. Turn down service didn't even include a mint on your pillow. All of the staff, however, were very nice and helpful. And the grounds are breathtaking. Then there are the pools. And the kids. We're from Florida. If we wanted to be surrounded by screaming, overindulged kids, we could have saved a lot of money and just gone to Disney World for our honeymoon. We also had trouble getting seats at the adult pool and just could not believe the swim-up bar wasn't at the adult pool. We didn't even try that. What were they thinking? We didn't even try for a cabana, but they weren't in my opinion even that private or nice for the money. And, when we sat out on the lawn by the adult pool, we had a bunch of kids playing hide and seek all around there one day and parent playing catch with his kid another day. The first day we were there, there were kids in the adult pool. I feel the need to add here that we both actually like kids. Well behaved, respectful ones. I was left wondering what the deal was with the parents at the Fairmont. Do they all have nannies and don't know how to deal with their kids on their own on vacation? And what happened to the day when there was a degree of decorum expected when one stayed at a place such as this? We never did eat at Nick's because we couldn't get a reservation. I believe our food on our wedding night was from there, and it was very good. We had in-suite dining a couple nights and it was always good. We also at Cafe Ciao one night and it was delicious. But this comes back to the "what are they thinking" thing again. The deli/cafe is directly behind it, so again, a romantic patio dinner, with screaming kids in the background. I am SO glad we didn't pay for the romantic dinner in the poolside cabana on our wedding night (which we seriously considered) because that would have been the same thing for $375. The final kicker for us was the night before our wedding, when the Fairmont had a charity event on the patio directly below our room. Also noisy and annoying. (We're not against charity either, we both do a lot of volunteer work ourselved). We just didn't expect this kind of lack of consideration fromt he Fairmont. I'm sure they managed to profit from that little affair also. All in all, I think they have a lot of nerve charging what they charge for what they offer and we will not be likely to ever return again. One of our next planned trips is to Bermuda and we had planned on staying at the Fairmont there too, but after this experience will definitely not. We have both stayed at similarly rated hotels previously (Four Seasons at Las Colinas, Ritz Carlton in Naples, The Breakers at Palm Beach and even the Hyatt Regency Westshore in Tampa all come to mind) and been thoroughly delighted by them all. That all said, we still had a lovely, private wedding on a local beach and great honeymoon.

Reviews.Title: “This Hotel caters to kids!!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My husband suprised me By booking the Kea Lani for our Maui part of our Honeymoon. Our previous stays at The Madairn Oriental, and the Farimount on the Big Island were relaxing and enjoyable. If you are on a romantic trip or just want to relax, DO NOT STAY HERE! This hotel should give you a warning about the amount of familys that stay thier. Kids were ever were,even in the only area which was supposed to be the adult only pool. What a joke, this was the most annoying part, not only was it over crowded by other trying to escape loud, screaming kids, but If you were not up early enough to get a chair you were out of luck. Stay at the Four Seasons for a adult vacation.

Reviews.Title: “Better than we expected”
Reviews.Author: backfromvacation
Reviews.Content: My wife and I stayed 7 nights at the Fairmont for our honeymoon. We arrived at the Fairmont after a week in Oahu staying at the Hilton. We expected the Fairmont to be the same as the Hilton, we were so wrong. The Firmont really felt like a palace from a different time, very classy. The open walkways were lined with shops and spas. Views of the ocean and pools were breathtaking and almost made us forget we were on vacation. You just have to see it for yourself. Our room was on the far end of the hotel (a long walk) and it didnâ€™t have an ocean view. The very nice bathroom had a big tub and shower. There was a separate sitting area with a TV and stereo, this was a nice extra. My wife and I thought it was nice that a maid would clean the room twice in one day. We would wake up, make a mess of our room go out and have fun, come back and it was clean. We would go out for dinner and came back for the turndown service; this was also a nice extra. The Fairmont was not as busy as the Hilton in Oahu and it really felt as if you had the place to yourself. The pools were never over crowded and walking through the hotel was quiet. The beaches were almost empty and this was a really nice change of pace for us. Service was better than expected, sitting by the pool or having dinner at Nick's Fishmarket on site. If we wanted to go to a different restaurant we would call the front desk and they would suggest something, they would call that restaurant and make the reservations for us. If you didnâ€™t want to drive your rental car (you need a rental car on Maui) the Fairmont offered a nice Cadillac service to drive you where you wanted to go, within reason of-course. The Cadillac service was not advertised and we were told by other gusts of the hotel that it could be done, and we used it. One of the best examples of good service I can give would be our scuba adventure. We were sitting by the pool one early morning and a Fairmont employee suggested we take a dive. My wife and I never thought of doing it and a 30min crash course dive in the pool and we were ready. We were only a short walk away from the hotel, just off the beach. Our instructor told us this is a good spot to see sea turtles and he was right. I could go on and on about the good service. Sunsets at the Fairmont were always breathtaking. The hotels beach is on the west side of the island, and you are never going to miss the sun going down. It is a very romantic, quiet hotel with lots of wonderful extras. See pictures of the Fairmont on my website www.eyestothesky.net

Reviews.Title: “nice hotel, but not the best”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My boyfriend and I spent the second half of our Hawaii vacation (Aug 14-19) in Maui. Like usual, Maui was gorgeous and fun and the weather was beautiful, so we would have enjoyed staying anywhere decent. The Fairmont was very nice, very big, clean, palacial, had a nice beach, etc., but there were other hotels that would have been nicer, or similar for less money. For the cost of the Kea Lani, you're much better off staying at the Ritz, etc. If the room rate was less, I would have been much more impressed, but I was expecting the most grand hotel I've ever stayed at and it wasn't even close. The staff were all wonderful and very accomodating, juice and leis upon arrival, but all the reviews about the rooms and the pools are true. Carpets and popcorn ceilings definitely need updating, and to get a chaise by the pool is a joke. I think the Farimont Villas are the way to go if you want to stay at this hotel. Much prettier accomodations, closer to the beach, more modern, and a few good celebrity sightings if you're into that. All in all we had a fantastic time, but will most likely stay somewhere else the next time around. They do serve the BEST bloody mary I've ever had out at the pool though. Don't miss it!!!

Reviews.Title: “Lush Paradise...Just remember to "Renovate"”
Reviews.Author: TheGoul
Reviews.Content: After reading all the recent review of the Fairmont Kea Lani, and finally experiencing the real thing for myself, I must warn all future travelers that there appears to be a genuine and viable reason for the discrepancy in the reviews posted here, and I can sum it up in one word: "Renovated." The official word from the hotel is that they are not quite at the 50% mark yet, which means that less than half the rooms have been renovated. Now what does that mean to you? Well, I originally requested a renovated room, but upon check-in was told that I was assigned a non-renovated room. I did a little arm twisting, and was quickly given a renovated room...which was beautiful! I did sneak a few peeks at some non-renovated rooms, and there was a stark contrast: The non-renovated rooms were very bland, lots of white couches and furniture that looked fairly old and worn. Our renovated room on the other hand was brand new, with aqua colored couches, nice mix of dark and light woods, etc. The bathroom was spectacular, with separate bathtub and shower (shower was actually tucked in around a wall,) separate pedestal sinks and doors at either end - one leading to your bedroom, the other leading to the hallway. Now, I have been at many Four Seasons hotels around the world, and yes, their bedrooms tend to be "slightly" classier and a little "plusher," but seriously...would you rather be in the standard 300-500 square foot Four Seasons room or in a nearly 900 square feet Fairmont room? And for 6 days of living...who cares if your lamp is from Tiffany's or not! The renovated rooms at the Kea Lani are beautiful AND extremely spacious, with a separate bedroom that's closed off from a living room with a huge wraparound couch, a second TV set, CD/DVD player, wet bar with a nice size fridge...what more could one ask? I can see however, how some people could be upset flying all the way to Maui, paying all that money, and then getting an older, slightly run down room (especially when they know that newer rooms DO exist at the same property!). That's a tough call to make...but keep in mind that the rooms are huge no matter what shape they're in, and how much time did you really expect to spend in your room after flying all this way to Maui? In my opinion, it's worth the chance to request a renovated room, and if you don't get one than you should push for one, and if that doesn't work...the resort itself is nice enough that in the long run, it won't really matter that much. As for the rest of the place, it's all first rate. Now, will they have people waiting at the pool to lay out your towels, no? That's a nice touch, but just because they don't do that here doesn't mean the service is bad. Anything we asked for, we received with no hassle. I even wanted to use the Internet but not pay $10 a day, so the nice lady at the concierge let me use the computers in the business center for free anytime I wanted. While the pool cabanas did cost money to rent ($75), the valet parking was absolutely free, all day, every day! The adult pool was very quiet and very large and nearly empty most of the time, which was nice. The other pool is actually two pools, and upper and lower pool, and they are connected by a great waterslide. The slide entrance is actually located IN the upper pool, so you don't have to even get out of the water to slide down to the bottom pool. There is a great swim up bar at the upper pool as well, and the bartenders were always quick and witty. The bottom pool had a nice waterfall at one end, an island in the middle to swim around, a small bridge to swim under, as well a basketball hoop at another end. But the basketball games never intruded on the rest of the pool area because there was so much room to swim. A large grass area heading down toward the beach was always open for sunbathers or watching the sunset, but the beach area was the magical part of the hotel. Never crowded, it was the most amazing place to watch the sun go down. There were always lots of chairs to lay back and relax in a secluded part of the beach, except for the one or two couples who came down daily to have their picture taken immediately after their wedding reception...truly another world. My only complaintâ€¦for the sheer size and beauty of the resortâ€¦how they could have the tiniest little spa is absolutely beyond me. Was it nice? Yes. Was the massage great? Yes. But beyond the front desk area, the entire spa consisted of a small narrow hallway which contained two small locker rooms and maybe five or so treatment rooms. The locker room had only two or three small showers and one small steam room. I do like to get my massages in the same hotel where Iâ€™m staying just for the convenience, but for those who want to make a day or even a half day of it, youâ€™re better off going up to the Four Seasons or the Grand Wailea. But all that being said, this is a 4 Â½ star resort if youâ€™re in a renovated room and 4 stars in a non-renovated room, but in terms of value for your money and the size of the rooms, it almost feels like a 5 star.

Reviews.Title: “there are way better hotels out there”
Reviews.Author: chrys
Reviews.Content: We have just returned from a month in Hawaii, staying at 4 different hotels (one on each island). Regrettably, the Kea Lani received the lowest grade, in our opinion. It was terribly busy night and day, and while the service was good at the restaurants, the wait for breakfast or lunch sometimes exceeded an hour. However, the biggest problem, by far, was that you had to rise by 6 a.m to get a pool chair with any shade. If you left it until 8 a.m. or so, there was NOTHING with shade left, and you would be hard pressed to find a chair anywhere. If you went to the beach, you could rent beach umberellas for $35 per day, but if there are more than 2 or you, you need two umberellas, so its pretty expensive. Once down at the beach, its a long way back to get a drink or food. Other guests told us that this occurred the year previously as well at the Failrmont, so its notlike its a new issue. The cabanas ($75 per day) may be booked in advance, so they were all taken as well for the entire time we were at the Fairmont, but guests may cancel their cabana reservation as late as the morning of the reservation, so if you are on the waiting list, you still have to get up very early to get chairs, which you can then give up if your number on the wait list gets called...what a goofey system. The room amenities are good (little fridge, microwave and coffee maker), but we had to switch rooms due to the ants invading our kitchen in the first room. Then next room was better, but still not completely clear of ants. We were told that our suite would sleep 5, but it only had beds for 4 (sofa sleeper and king bed), and were then charged $30 per night for a cot. The pool system is fairly small and gets quite crowded. Our kids are 11 and 13 and grew bored of the pool pretty quickly because there is no room to play without hitting someone else. We thought that the other hotels that at which we stayed (Prince in Big Island and Sheraton in Kauai) were far superior to the Fairmont Kea Lani. We really enjoyed staying at each of those and would go back in a second. We would not go back to the Fairmont.

Reviews.Title: “The best choice....”
Reviews.Author: miltonwar
Reviews.Content: We past the most wonderful honeymoon in Maui, and of course, we love the place we stay, the Fairmont, is the most romantic, good looking, finest hotel, in every aspect...and expensive too, but it worth. First of all, the free valet parking is really good, they make all their effort in order to take the minimum time to give your car, and when you arrive, forget about looking where to park, just pick your shopping bags, and walk to your room. The Suites are amazing, with a little and functional kitchen with fridge, a tv/dvd/radio room, really nice, good sound, and you can relax there watching some movie or knowing what to do in the information channel provided by Fairmont, the bath are really nice, big ones, you`ll see the pics, and the bed is really nice, and of course you`ll have a Lanai, where we took an insuite breakfast (by far, the best room service ever..). We were treated like a kings, all the staff trying to remember our names, and the best thing, as we were members of the president club (just sign in by internet, said the number and you`ll get free island calls (great for reservations), free internet (it cost U$10 half hour), and free news paper every day (maui news, or Usa Today), and many extras more.... We take the romantic package (it is really romantic) who includes..the first night a bottle of champagne, and strawberries with chocolate, we receive two picture holders, and we had a Sunset Cruise in Maale'a, a romantic Dinner in Cafe Ciao, in the pool area (very romantic, good food, and good attention)...you`ll see the picture I took... and a lot of extras more...ah, almost forgot the Lomi lomi massage at the SPA, a tip....take the Spa the last day, we did that and was the best idea. The pools are very nice, they had painting flowers in the bottom...there are three pools, two of them are for the family, and one is for adults, they are so clean and nice size. There are a lot of space to seat, and if you want a chair by the pool you should get one early, but it is not necessary. The beach is very nice, quiet, not good for snorkeling, but its nice. The area from the pool is a dream, you can take a look from the hotel and is amazing, (kea lani means heavenly white), and its true. Almost all the time there are towels in the towel areas. One of the best restaurants in Maui is the Nick`s at fish Market, you should make a reservation (not necessary), and the service and food is amazing. The Hotel is great, the architecture is nice...at night you can see the torchs they use to iluminate the areas...when we arrive from airport all the way from the car main entrance was this way, is romantic, amazing, and cool...you really feel you are in Maui. We had a montain view, but we can see the sea from there, nice views. If you have to choose, choose Fairmont Kea Lani, and if you are on a honeymoon, take the romantic package. Enjoy the pics.

Reviews.Title: “Kea Lani Is The Best”
Reviews.Author: Bob_LSanJose_CA
Reviews.Content: Stayed at the Kea Lani with an upgrade from American Express Fine Resorts. Got an Ocean View, next to the poolside Grill. Short walk to the beach. The room was newly renovated and huge. The Polo Beach was so much fun - the waves are a blast. You are a wuss if you didnt like the waves. Highly recommended.

Reviews.Title: “What a disappointment!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My husband and I literally just came home today from a two week trip to Hawaii (staying at Halekulani on Oahu, Manele Bay in Lana'i and the Fairmont in Maui.)
